awd_titl_txt: The Role of Multi-Scale Porosity on Termite Mound Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
Termite mounds provide an excellent example of naturally-built habitats that are efficient and resilient. Mound construction is achieved through efficient use of local materials without the need for a heat-beat-treat cycle often employed in the development of man-made materials. The mounds are also nature's model for combined structural and mechanical systems providing ventilation and temperature regulation solely through the form of the structure. An understanding of the natural processes involved in termite mound construction and function can be adapted to inform engineering applications related to the construction of man-made structures that require zero or minimal energy inputs. Also, as termites micro-3D-print mounds, this work can inform new paradigms in 3D-printed human structures. The transdisciplinary project will lead to advances in materials and structural forms that are informed by the construction methods of termites for structures that require significantly less energy and are more sustainable than traditional construction. Research outcomes will move the U.S. toward greater energy independence and security. Technology transfer of new materials and systems will grow manufacturing and strengthen national economic development.
 
The overall goal of the project is to inform new processes for sustainable bio-inspired building systems and bio-cemented materials using locally available materials. This will be accomplished by identifying the thermal and mechanical properties of termite mounds as systems and the chemical, thermal and mechanical properties of the bio-cemented soil using the multi-scale porosity of the structure and material as the key parameter. The complex nano-to-mega-scale structure of the termite mounds will be analyzed using a suite of advanced techniques. 3D models of the macro-to-mega-scale pore structure of termite mounds will be developed by photogrammetric mapping their exterior and by imaging slices of cast molds of the interior tunnel structure. The nano-to-meso-scale pore structure of harvested bio-cemented material will be measured using nitrogen adsorption, mercury intrusion porosimetry, and high-resolution X-ray micro-computed tomography. Including porosity in consideration of homeostasis of termite mounds provides information on the importance of material properties in mound ventilation, thermal and structural characteristics. Studying the ability of termites to regulate systems through the synergy of the structural topology and unique materials can be a starting point for engineering designers to use local materials efficiently and adaptively.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This award, The Role of Multi-Scale Porosity on Termite Mound Behavior, was an opportunity for team science that involved expertise of insect ecologists, biologists, materials scientists, structural and geotechnical engineers to study the fundamental properties and biomimetic opportunities of the mound material of higher order fungus farming termites. Our team traveled to southern Africa to field sites in the north of the country where the flat, open terrain of the desert Savannah provided an ideal setting for data collection, measurements, observations, sample collection and eexperiments. Samples from field work in Africa were brought under USDA and African soil export and import permits to the United States for further analyses and experimentation. Our field work and eexperiments included mapping and analysis of the porosity (pore volume compared to total volume) and pore structures of termite mound materials, as constructed by the termites. The goals were to 1) understand what and why the termites were building the mounds as they are, 2) understand fundamental principles of material composition and pore structures, and 3) develop man-made analogs that have potential for low-cost sustainable building materials and systems. 

This study was driven by observations of how the termites build and sustain the mounds to regulate temperatures and methane gasses within the colony that lives in the nest below the visible mound, under the ground. The mounds are hard, hard as some sedimentary rocks. How do the termites make the material so hard? Are there secrets to their tunnel structures that can inform how we build human ventilation systems? These questions helped us form our hypotheses which drove this project. 

Field measurements included in-situ measurements of mound material strength, water content, thermal conductivity, and composition. We also mapped the internal structures of mounds, while developing three-dimensional models of the mound exteriors. Our studies included trenching aside mounds to study their tunnels that extent away from the nest and mound out to the where the termites harvest woody biomass. Mapping of internal pore structures included zinc casts and also "slice-and-scan" imaging with photogrammetry. We use structure-from-motion techniques to develop high quality 3D images of the external mound structures. 

Back in the laboratory, the material of the mound is studied in detail, from its basic mineral and biological composition, micro- and nano-level porosity and pore structures, and the organic constituents residual to the termite construction process. All along the way, the strength of the mound material as a function of water content and saturation were measured carefully. Novel means of measuring strength were developed due to the small sample sizes and irregular shapes of mound samples that were able to be collected. Imaging of the internal porosity included micro-CT X-ray imaging and use of Nitrogen Gas "BET" saturation methods. We also extracted the DNA of microbes left in the mound material from the termites to study the role of microbes in the mound construction process. Thermal conductivities were gathered to help us understand the heat exchange of the mound as well as the gas exchange that the termites leverage in their design and build. 

As our data collected and experimentation progressed, it became clear that the thermal conductivity and micro- to nano-level porosities were very similar to the native African soil. While the shear mass of the mound, rather than its pore structure, controls heat diffusion. However, the remarkable strength gain was shown to be partially from carbon mineral precipitation via both enzymes and microbes, but mostly from the organic compound residuals from termite saliva and urine. Unlike woody biomass reinforcement (such as straw in bricks), the organic residuals of sugars, proteins, and fats are contributing to the strength of the material as well as its increase in overall porosity, which aids the gas and thermal exchange in the mound. A synthetic termite saliva/urine was developed from studying these properties, which produces strength gains comparable to the same mass or volume of Portland Cement when added to identical soils. For 6% by mass low-cost, sustainable, naturally occurring compounds, we were able to reach strengths and durability of material comparable to 6% Portland Cement addition to the same soil. 

We thank the peoples of southern Africa for their cooperation, help, and assistance in this study. We could not have done the science without them.


Last Modified: 08/08/2023
Modified by: Bret N Lingwall
